newsitem.title: UK: UK says U.S. attacked southern Iraq targets.
newsitem.headline: UK says U.S. attacked southern Iraq targets.

text.p: Britain said on Tuesday that the United States attacked targets in southern Iraq after Saddam Hussein was informed of an extension to the no-fly zone there.
A statement from Prime Minister John Major's office said: "The U.S. government has confirmed that attacks have been made on military sites in southern Iraq."

The statement said: "The Iraqi authorities were notified earlier today of an extension to the no fly zone in southern Iraq in response to the recent masive buildup of Iraqi military forces and the attack on Arbil."

Britain fully supported the U.S. attack, which the statement described as "this unequivocal message to Saddam Hussein that repression of innocent civilians and reckless acts of brutality are unacceptable."

The extension of the no-fly zones -- first imposed after the Gulf War by the U.S.-led anti-Iraq coalition -- was aimed at keeping Iraqi forces under close surveillance and making clear to Saddam Hussein that his persecution of civilians and "reckless behaviour" was intolerable, the statement from 10 Downing Street said.
